entry.title: Significance of Origin Key in BTP Trust, especially sap.custom
entry.content:
Hi all,

we are about to onboard SAP Digital Manufacturing. With this comes BTP and establishing trust between subaccount and Cloud Integration Services.

That being said, when using the "Establish Trust" wizard, the default value for "Origin Key" will be "sap.custom".

I know about the overall posibility to use multiple Origin Key values to separate different IdPs / trusts within one subaccount, something that is feasible but not the norm, see Using Multiple Identity Providers from the Same Subaccount, however, I'm unsure about the significance of the wizard's default value "sap.custom"

My questions

  1. Is there some kind of built in "fallback" or hard wired lookup for "sap.custom"? In other words, would it be a bad idea to not have at least one entry with "sap.custom" (providing we are going the route of using Cloud Identity Services and not the default IdP)
  2. For our use case we have SAP Digital Manufacturing deployed in the subaccount and nothing more. Am I right that in this case it might be just fine to stay with the "sap.custom" moniker or is it (when planning ahead) a good idea to apply a more meaningful naming convention? And if so, what should I name the darn thing then? cis_dev (for cloud identity services development environment / tier) or something else?

Many thanks and cheers

J

entry.title: Role Collection Assignment to SAP BTP Platform User via Groups in SAP Cloud Identity is not working
entry.content:
Role Collection Assignment to SAP BTP Platform User via Groups in SAP Cloud Identity Service is not working.

 

1). Create Trust between SAP Cloud Identity Service and Global Account in SAP BTP.

2) Create Users in SAP Cloud Identity Service Admin Console.

3) Created user in SAP BTP Global account with email identifier same as point-2.Assign Role in BTP Platform.

3) User is able to log in to SAP BTP Platform Global Account.

>>>>>>>>>>>>> IDENTITY AUTHENTICATION IS WORKING<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<

 

1) CREATED GROUP IN SAP Cloud Identity Service Admin Console with group type AUTHORISATION and enabled Central Store-Based Provisioning in Application Setting for SAP BTP Application.

2) Mapped above created group to role collection in Global Account in SAP BTP Platform.

3) Assigned user group to user in SAP Cloud Identity Service Admin Console.

 

Logged in Logged out multiple times, in different browser but role assigned via group is not effective.

entry.title: CF Deployment failed with DCL files deployment in Cloud Identity Service instance BTP
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I was having issues deploying my CAP application along with DCL files for achieving RBAC & ABAC (Authorization checks) to BTP, running into a deploy issue:

So I started from scratch with a simple application: 

- Install a fresh Trial Account

- Create a HANA DB (mapping to CF dev space)

- Create a simple CAP application in BAS, single table, simple service to display table entries

- Add hana (for production), Add mta

- Create MTA file

- Deploy to CF

I referred the below url’s for adding & deploying  DCL files with AMS authoization checks(RBAC & ABAC).

 

  • https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/cap-java-implementation-for-authorization-...
  • https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/authorization-management-service-in-sap-cl...

 

All vanilla steps, explained in many blogs and CAPIRE. Nothing special, no manipulation of any package.json or any other files. 

However, no matter what I do. I always run into a CF deploy issue  :

I am trying to explore the concept of AMS(Authoriztion Management System) with RBAC& ABAC. I have created the CAPM application in SAP BTP by using BAS(Business Application Studio). Also, I have configured the deployment properties in mta.yaml file . The application is deployed with Cloud Identity Service instance in CF(Cloud Foundry ) environment with out any issues. But, DCL files are not deployed and getting the errors . I tried out in different ways and failed. Added the logs below for your reference:

 
#2025 04 09 12:08:40.398#Z#DEBUG#c49d6141-153a-11f0-9569-eeee0a831419.btp-cap-java-cloud-identity-demo-main-ams-policies-deployer#flowable-async-job-executor-thread-134#
[PollStageAppStatusExecution] 46d8770d-e2ca-45c8-957e-2546dfdd5277 [2025-04-09T11:58:35.168784] Invoking pre-start scripts. (STDOUT, APP/TASK/deploy-dcl)#
#2025 04 09 12:08:40.398#Z#DEBUG#c49d6141-153a-11f0-9569-eeee0a831419.btp-cap-java-cloud-identity-demo-main-ams-policies-deployer#flowable-async-job-executor-thread-134#
[PollStageAppStatusExecution] 46d8770d-e2ca-45c8-957e-2546dfdd5277 [2025-04-09T11:58:35.318862] Invoking start command. (STDOUT, APP/TASK/deploy-dcl)#
#2025 04 09 12:08:40.398#Z#DEBUG#c49d6141-153a-11f0-9569-eeee0a831419.btp-cap-java-cloud-identity-demo-main-ams-policies-deployer#flowable-async-job-executor-thread-134#
[PollStageAppStatusExecution] 46d8770d-e2ca-45c8-957e-2546dfdd5277 [2025-04-09T11:58:35.632962] npm error code ENOENT (STDERR, APP/TASK/deploy-dcl)#
#2025 04 09 12:08:40.398#Z#DEBUG#c49d6141-153a-11f0-9569-eeee0a831419.btp-cap-java-cloud-identity-demo-main-ams-policies-deployer#flowable-async-job-executor-thread-134#
[PollStageAppStatusExecution] 46d8770d-e2ca-45c8-957e-2546dfdd5277 [2025-04-09T11:58:35.633116] npm error syscall open (STDERR, APP/TASK/deploy-dcl)#
#2025 04 09 12:08:40.398#Z#DEBUG#c49d6141-153a-11f0-9569-eeee0a831419.btp-cap-java-cloud-identity-demo-main-ams-policies-deployer#flowable-async-job-executor-thread-134#
[PollStageAppStatusExecution] 46d8770d-e2ca-45c8-957e-2546dfdd5277 [2025-04-09T11:58:35.633302] npm error path /home/vcap/app/package.json (STDERR, APP/TASK/deploy-dcl)#
#2025 04 09 12:08:40.398#Z#DEBUG#c49d6141-153a-11f0-9569-eeee0a831419.btp-cap-java-cloud-identity-demo-main-ams-policies-deployer#flowable-async-job-executor-thread-134#
[PollStageAppStatusExecution] 46d8770d-e2ca-45c8-957e-2546dfdd5277 [2025-04-09T11:58:35.633689] npm error errno -2 (STDERR, APP/TASK/deploy-dcl)#
#2025 04 09 12:08:40.398#Z#DEBUG#c49d6141-153a-11f0-9569-eeee0a831419.btp-cap-java-cloud-identity-demo-main-ams-policies-deployer#flowable-async-job-executor-thread-134#
[PollStageAppStatusExecution] 46d8770d-e2ca-45c8-957e-2546dfdd5277 [2025-04-09T11:58:35.633751] npm error enoent Could not read package.json: Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, open '/home/vcap/app/package.json' (STDERR, APP/TASK/deploy-dcl)#
#2025 04 09 12:08:40.398#Z#DEBUG#c49d6141-153a-11f0-9569-eeee0a831419.btp-cap-java-cloud-identity-demo-main-ams-policies-deployer#flowable-async-job-executor-thread-134#
[PollStageAppStatusExecution] 46d8770d-e2ca-45c8-957e-2546dfdd5277 [2025-04-09T11:58:35.633810] npm error enoent This is related to npm not being able to find a file. (STDERR, APP/TASK/deploy-dcl)#
#2025 04 09 12:08:40.398#Z#DEBUG#c49d6141-153a-11f0-9569-eeee0a831419.btp-cap-java-cloud-identity-demo-main-ams-policies-deployer#flowable-async-job-executor-thread-134#

I can't find any valuable information on this error, other than some non SAP related blogs mentioning that the stacks are not available on CF. As I did a clean install on a Trial account I assume the BTP environment is installed correctly. 

Would be great if somebody could provide some hints as I'm not able to deploy any application with DCL files  to BTP.

Regards,

Umasankarseelan

entry.title: Error in SAP Mobile Services and Cloud Connector without main propagation
entry.content:
Hi community,

I'm facing a persistent issue with SAP Mobile Services and SAP Cloud Connector.

📌 Scenario:

  • I have a mobile application configured in SAP Mobile Services.

  • The destination points to an on-premise system via Cloud Connector.

  • Destination configuration:

    • Type: Cloud Connector

    • Authentication: Basic Authentication

    • User propagation: Disabled

  • In the mobile app:

    • Security is configured as OAuth (via XSUAA)

❗ Problem:

Even though authentication is set to Basic and principal propagation is disabled, Cloud Connector keeps logging the following warning repeatedly:

The Cloud Connector has not been configured for principal propagation. Please configure it or discontinue sending the SSO token in the request.

This happens every time the mobile app calls the destination.

❓ Question:

How can I prevent SAP Mobile Services from sending the SSO (Bearer) token when using a destination with Basic Authentication?
Is there any way to force SAP Mobile Services not to send the OAuth token, even if the app is secured with OAuth?

Any help or experience from someone who has solved this in a similar scenario would be greatly appreciated.

Destination: 

Cloud connector:

 

Logs:

2025-06-11 08:47:03,615 -0500#WARN#com.sap.core.connectivity.protocol.http.handlers.HttpNoAuthenticationHandler#tunnel-client-804-7#0x79d8e706#The Cloud Connector has not been configured for principal propagation. Please configure it or discontinue sending the SSO token in the request.|
2025-06-11 08:47:03,944 -0500#WARN#com.sap.core.connectivity.protocol.http.handlers.HttpNoAuthenticationHandler#tunnel-client-804-7#0xf425f394#The Cloud Connector has not been configured for principal propagation. Please configure it or discontinue sending the SSO token in the request.|
2025-06-11 08:47:04,459 -0500#WARN#com.sap.core.connectivity.protocol.http.handlers.HttpNoAuthenticationHandler#tunnel-client-804-7#0xc45ba802#The Cloud Connector has not been configured for principal propagation. Please configure it or discontinue sending the SSO token in the request.|
2025-06-11 08:47:10,583 -0500#WARN#com.sap.core.connectivity.protocol.http.handlers.HttpNoAuthenticationHandler#tunnel-client-804-7#0x043ba202#The Cloud Connector has not been configured for principal propagation. Please configure it or discontinue sending the SSO token in the request.|
2025-06-11 08:47:13,150 -0500#WARN#com.sap.core.connectivity.protocol.http.handlers.HttpNoAuthenticationHandler#tunnel-client-804-7#0x836b866c#The Cloud Connector has not been configured for principal propagation. Please configure it or discontinue sending the SSO token in the request.|
2025-06-11 08:47:14,072 -0500#WARN#com.sap.core.connectivity.protocol.http.handlers.HttpNoAuthenticationHandler#tunnel-client-804-7#0x62a66969#The Cloud Connector has not been configured for principal propagation. Please configure it or discontinue sending the SSO token in the request.|
2025-06-11 08:47:21,714 -0500#WARN#com.sap.core.connectivity.protocol.http.handlers.HttpNoAuthenticationHandler#tunnel-client-804-7#0x09a22876#The Cloud Connector has not been configured for principal propagation. Please configure it or discontinue sending the SSO token in the request.|
2025-06-11 08:47:21,933 -0500#WARN#com.sap.core.connectivity.protocol.http.handlers.HttpNoAuthenticationHandler#tunnel-client-804-7#0x26fd940c#The Cloud Connector has not been configured for principal propagation. Please configure it or discontinue sending the SSO token in the request.|
2025-06-11 08:47:23,808 -0500#WARN#com.sap.core.connectivity.protocol.http.handlers.HttpNoAuthenticationHandler#tunnel-client-804-7#0x58380bba#The Cloud Connector has not been configured for principal propagation. Please configure it or discontinue sending the SSO token in the request.|

 

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: How to Configure SFTP Authentication in SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) – A Step-by-Step Guide
entry.content:
SFTP Configuration and Usage Guide

 

* Access the SFTP Platform

  • Visit the URL:https://sftpcloud.io/tools/free-sftp-server
  • Click on the Login button located at the top right corner.

* Sign Up / Log In

  • Use the 'Sign Up / Log In' option to register or enter your account.

* Create SFTP instance

  • After a successful login, To Create New SFTP instance.

  • Next, Open the SFTP instance, click on 'Users', and then go to 'Connection Details’.

After configure SFTP server, we will have some info of it as

  • User name
  • Password phrase
  • Host name
  • SFTP Port

* Install WinSCP

  • Visit the URL:https://winscp.net/eng/download.php
  • Open WinSCP and login using the Host Name, User Name, and Password from the SFTP server.

  • Here, we create a directory or file in WinSCP to upload or download files from the SFTP server.

* Create Known Host in CPI
  1. Go to integration Suite Application
  2. Go to Design integration flow
  3. Go to Monitor item in left menu
  4. Go to Connectivity Test

  • Open Notepad, paste the Host Key, and save the file with an appropriate name (e.g., hostkey.txt).
  • Add this known host into CPI

* Create User Credentials

  1. Go to integration Suite Application
  2. Go to Design integration flow
  3. Go to Monitor item in left menu
  4. Go to Security Material
  5. Click on create

* To check the user credentials, go to 'Connectivity Test' and click on 'SSH'.

1. Username/Password :-

 

  • SFTP SENDER IFLOW

     Create/Configure an Integration Flow

  1. We are using HTTPS to send the data {\"productIdentifier\":\"HT-2000\"} because this value needs to be passed to the OData service.

  1. The JSON to XML Converter is used to convert incoming JSON data into XML, as required by the OData service.

  1. Use the Content Modifier to assign information to headers.

  1. Use the Request-Reply step to fetch product details from the OData service.

  1. The OData service is being accessed from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub (api.sap.com).

In the SAP Business Accelerator Hub, navigate to APIs → ODATA V2, then search for 'Product Master'.

 Click on "Show API Key" to get the key needed for authentication.

In the API Specification, you can download the OData EDMX, which is useful when integrating in SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) for OData service modeling.

In the Configuration Details section, the Sandbox URL helps in forming the complete endpoint URL by replacing the {host} placeholder with the actual hostname when configuring the OData connection in SAP Cloud Integration (CPI).

  1. Now in the connection, use the Sandbox URL as the Address.

We are using the data {\"productIdentifier\":\"HT-2000\"} to retrieve the specific product details from the OData service.

  1. Next, use the XML to CSV Converter to send data to the receiver, as the SFTP server only accepts CSV format.
  2. The SFTP Adapter is configured at the receiver end to deliver the converted CSV file.The directory and address are taken from the SFTP server, the file name is created dynamically, and the credentials are retrieved from the security material.
  3. Next, save and deploy the integration. Then, open Manage Integration Content and copy the Endpoint URL.

     

  4. Go to Postman, select the GET method, and paste the endpoint URL.

In the Auth type, select OAuth 2.0, and provide the Client ID, Client Secret, and Token URL from the service instance. Then, click Get New Access Token.

Provide the body data, click on Send, and view the result.

  1.  Now, go to WinSCP, where you can see the CSV file or data in the specified directory.

 

 

  • SFTP RECEIVER IFLOW

Create/Configure an Integration Flow

  1. Open or create an Integration Flow (iFlow).
  2. Connect the sender participant to Start and select the SFTP as adapter. Configure the SFTP adapter as per requirements.

Make sure that the SFTP credentials are deployed in the below path

Overview --> Manage Security --> Security Material --> Create/Upload Credentials

Check the connectivity test of SFTP adapter in Test Connectivity in the below path

Overview --> Manage Security --> Connectivity Tests --> SSH

Copy the Host Key and paste it in notepad & deploy it in Known Hosts(SSH) file in the below path.

Overview --> Manage Security --> Security Material --> Upload Known Hosts(SSH)

  1.  In the processing tab also configure as per your requirement whether you want to Archive, Keep File and Process Again.

  1. In the scheduler tab also we need to choose how many times this particular interface needs to be run.

  1. Use the CSV to XML Converter to transform the incoming CSV file into structured XML format.

  1. After saving and deploying the integration, go to Monitor → Message Processing → Message Processing Run, click on the end of the run to view the XML data.

2. PUBLIC KEY :-

 

  • Create SSH KEY :
  1. Go to Monitor > Integrations and APIs, open Manage Keystore, click Create, and select SSH Key to generate a new SSH key.

  1. After creating the SSH key, click on the three dots (︙) and select Download Public OpenSSH Key.

Now open the SFTP server. In Windows PowerShell, run the following commands:

  • cd .\Downloads\ – to change the directory to Downloads
  • ls – to list the files and confirm your SSH key is there
  • cat <your_ssh_key_name>.pub – to display the public SSH key

  1. Copy the displayed public SSH key, open the SFTP server, navigate to Public Keys, paste the key, and click Save.

  • SFTP SENDER IFLOW

Using the same flows, just changing the authentication method from username/password to private key.

  1. Open the receiver SFTP adapter, select 'Public Key' for authentication, and provide the private key alias and the user name from the SFTP server.

  1. Next, save and deploy the integration. Then, open Manage Integration Content and copy the Endpoint URL.

  1. In the Auth type, select OAuth 2.0, and provide the Client ID, Client Secret, and Token URL from the service instance. Then, click Get New Access Token. Provide the body data, click on Send, and view the result.

  1. Now, go to WinSCP, where you can see the CSV file or data in the specified directory.

 

  • SFTP RECEIVER IFLOW
  1. Open the sender SFTP adapter, select 'Public Key' for authentication, and provide the private key alias and the user name from the SFTP server.

  1. After saving and deploying the integration, go to Monitor → Message Processing → Message Processing Run, click on the end of the run to view the XML data.

3. DUAL :-

 

  • SFTP SENDER IFOW

     Using the same flows, just changing the authentication method to Dual.

  1. Open the receiver SFTP adapter, select 'Dual' for authentication, and provide the private key alias and the Credential name.

  1. Next, save and deploy the integration. Then, open Manage Integration Content and copy the Endpoint URL.

  1. In the Auth type, select OAuth 2.0, and provide the Client ID, Client Secret, and Token URL from the service instance. Then, click Get New Access Token. Provide the body data, click on Send, and view the result.

  1. Now, go to WinSCP, where you can see the CSV file or data in the specified directory.

 

  • SFTP RECEIVER IFOW

      Using the same flows, just changing the authentication method to Dual.

  1. Open the receiver SFTP adapter, select 'Dual' for authentication, and provide the private key alias and the Credential name.

  1. After saving and deploying the integration, go to Monitor → Message Processing → Message Processing Run, click on the end of the run to view the XML data.

entry.title: [Free Tier] No IAS tenant available when trying to establish trust (SAP BTP)
entry.content:
Hello,

I'm using SAP BTP Free Tier (Pay-as-you-go) and trying to subscribe to services like SAP Build Work Zone and Launchpad.

However, when I try to "Establish Trust" in the subaccount, **no identity Authentication tenant is listed** in the tenant selection.

The screen just shows "No available tenant"

I alreay created an instance of "Cloud Identity Services(default)" in my subaccount. I also received an S-user via email.

Still, I cannot proceed because no IAS tenant is available for selection.

Here ar my details.

- Global Account ID: S0027108224

- Subaccount: dorandev

- Region: AWS South Korea

- Email: doran@doranlab.dev

How can I request or link an IAS tenant for this subaccount? Any help would be appreciated!

Thank you

entry.title: Assistance Required: Issues with SCI Check Process and Virus Scan Warning in SAP
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I am new to performing SCI checks in the SAP system and am currently facing an issue. Could someone please guide me through the process of performing SCI checks?

While executing the SCI check, I encountered a warning message: "Cannot Perform inspection: Virus scanner cannot be instantiated: Virus scan profile /SMIM_API/Put is not active." Since it is a warning, I proceeded further, but the results showed that no objects were processed, displaying zero. I have attached a snapshot of the result for your reference.

Could anyone advise on how to resolve this warning and ensure the SCI check processes the objects correctly? Any help would be greatly appreciated!

Thank you,
khaza Mohammad

entry.title: Wildcard usage in App Router routes & XSUAA redirect URIs (Multitenant)
entry.content:
Hi All,

I have developed a multitenant application using the SaaS Registry and successfully deployed it. However, I have a couple of queries regarding the use of wildcard characters in the configuration.

In the xs-security.json file, we have specified redirect URIs to support tenant onboarding without manual intervention. To generalize this, we used the pattern */<domain> for the redirect URIs. I would like to confirm whether this approach aligns with SAP's security policies, or if there is a recommended alternative for handling dynamic redirect URIs across tenants.

Secondly, our application uses the App Router. Currently, we are maintaining individual routes for each tenant subscription. To simplify this, we attempted to define a route using the */<domain> wildcard pattern. However, this does not seem to work as expected. Is there a supported method to configure a single route that applies to all subscribed tenants? Additionally, I would appreciate any guidance on the security implications of using such wildcard patterns in route configurations.

Looking forward to your suggestions and best practices.

Best regards,

Sunil Singireddy.

entry.title: BAS Connection to On-Premises System Failing with 'Request failed with status code 503'
entry.content:
Hello All,

I'm getting a The server returned an error. Request failed with status code 503 in SAP Business Application Studio when trying to connect to an on-premise system.

  • The system is connected successfully in Cloud Connector.

  • Destination is valid, and connection works in Build Apps , Business Automation Process.

  • BAS is the only place it's failing.

  • I have SAP_ALL access, and all required services are accessible as confirmed by  BASIS & SECURITY Team.

Did I miss any configuration on the on-premise system or in BAS? 

Also, is there a way to debug or trace this kind of issue from the BAS or backend side?

 

 

Additional Information:
When I performed the Fiori connection check to trace the issue, I encountered the following errors while establishing the connection in Business Application Studio (BAS):

  • OData V2 catalog service not available.

  • OData V4 catalog service not available.

  • Error: Cannot query V2 catalog service for DEV_001.

  • Error: Cannot query V4 catalog service for DEV_001.

 

 

Destination --> Check Connection

I'm completely new to the BAS application and would appreciate any guidance to help me understand and resolve this connection issue.

entry.title: Switching Cloud Identity tenant in Subaccount Trust Configuration
entry.content:
With OIDC Trusts in a Subaccount to Cloud Identity Services it's possible to switch the Cloud Identity tenant. You can simply edit the config and switch the tenant. User IDs and Authorizations remain untouched - everything works fine.

In the "old" Cloud Identity Tenant it even removes the Application and moves it to the "new" tenant.

Has anyone else used this in a production environment? Is this an official feature that's supported by SAP?

Regards

BTW here is how you can switch a Cloud Identity trust from SAML to OIDC:
Migrate from SAML Trust Configuration to OpenID Connect Trust with SAP Cloud Identity Services | SAP Help Portal

entry.title: Evaluating Risks of Non-VPN Access to SAP BTP Cockpit
entry.content:
Hello,

Is it standard practice for users to access the SAP BTP Cockpit using only company-issued S-user credentials—without requiring VPN or corporate network access? While this setup does offer convenience, it also raises potential security concerns. For instance, logging in from a personal device over the public internet, without any corporate network safeguards, could expose sensitive assets.
Would appreciate your thoughts on this. Thanks in advance.

Thanks

entry.title: Best Practice for Storing SAP User Passwords for Communication from BTP to SAP on-premise System
entry.content:
Hello Community,

I need advice on the best practice for storing passwords in an SAP BTP → SAP on Prem System communication scenario.

We are not using a technical user setup. Instead, each end user has their own SAP user and password for accessing the backend system. Since we have multiple systems and multiple users per system, I am considering two approaches:

Approach 1:

  • Store the password in a database after encrypting it.

  • Use a unique encryption key for each row.

  • Exclude the password and key fields from the OData service so they are not exposed on the UI.

Approach 2:

  • Store the credentials in the Destination service.

  • For 2 backend systems with 3 users, a total of 6 destinations would need to be created.

Has anyone faced a similar requirement? Which approach would be more secure and scalable? Or is there a better standard way recommended by SAP for handling such a scenario?

Thanks in advance for your guidance!

entry.title: Roles and role collections disappear after deployment
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I have been having trouble making role collections for the two applications. When I deploy first  application, the roles and role collections of the second application are deleted and vice versa. Both application are deployed in different spaces of same subaccount. The roles are defined in xs-security of applications. Not sure what exactly is happening. Can you point out what could be the exact root cause?

Regards,

Akshay

 

SAP BTP Security

entry.title: Provision of Sales Cloud V2 APIs via Integration Suite and Cloud Connector for on-prem clients
entry.content:
Dear colleagues,

As part of our ongoing platform transformation, we are migrating to Sales Cloud V2 and S/4HANA. Initial testing within our sandbox environment has confirmed successful access to the Sales Cloud V2 APIs.

For productive use, we aim to establish a secure and scalable integration architecture by leveraging SAP Integration Suite in conjunction with the Cloud Connector. This setup is intended to enable on-premise clients to proactively consume Sales Cloud V2 APIs.

The envisioned scenario involves external calls initiated from on-prem systems, with responses returned from the cloud — for example, accessing data related to the Business Partner object.

We would like to validate whether this architecture is technically feasible and aligns with best practices for hybrid connectivity and secure API exposure.

entry.title: Implementing IAS+AMS with BTP Applications
entry.content:
We're implementing IAS+AMS in which the use of XSUAA is eliminated. The implementation goes like this:

1. CAP application with IAS+AMS (separate app)

2. Generate Client ID and Secret in Cloud Identity Service as AMS uses X509 certificate
